content.description: The crux may be the start but is more so not falling, because the route is easy, but the land is not flat, and it’s quite rocky. The route begins on the smaller cobbles below two bigger ones. Bump to the larger cobbles, most obviously the large reddish one on the right. Aim for next cobble near the top out, and then find pretty solid holds above the lip to finish.
content.location:
It is a couple dozen yards from the boulders that hold “

Moray Eel

” and “

Oof

” on the creek side of the trail. It’s lower than the trail and can be accessed from left side of the boulder via two move scramble or the right side via trail. It’s closer to the edge of the little canyon, so stay away from the edge and close to the boulder.

content.description: SDS matched on the decent rail with your feet smearing. Move straight up, and top out without using the right arete. Using the arete makes for an easier, but still fun, problem.
content.location: Walk on the falls trail towards the falls, and look right. If you get close to the falls, you went quite a ways too far.

content.description: SDS under the roof. I match on the railing on the trailside of the boulder. Head up and around any way you'd like. Each direction up is V0-V1.
content.location: This boulder slightly hangs over the path. Be careful, your crashpad may be in the way of hikers.

content.description: Start on only landing on south side of small boulder. Climb middle of boulder using the cobbles but not the lower left. The “crux” is likely the bulge in the middle.
content.location:
It is a couple dozen yards from the boulders that hold “

Moray Eel

” and “

Oof

” on the creek side of the trail. It’s lower than the trail and can be accessed from left side of the boulder via two move scramble or the right side via trail. It’s closer to the edge of the little canyon, so stay away from the edge and close to the boulder.
